docs.lead_paragraph: When a New York State appeals court cleared the way for the city to start enforcing nearly decade-old regulations on conduct in its shelters this week, it re-opened an old debate on the extent to which society can hold the homeless responsible for improving their own condition. Until the decision on Tuesday, the rules were simple: the city had to shelter the homeless unless they were breaking the law. As a result of the decision, which advocates said they would appeal immediately, the city has won the right to temporarily evict men and women who violate regulations, for example, by stubbornly not pursuing a drug rehabilitation plan or by repeatedly vandalizing shelter property.
docs.abstract: News analysis of effect of New York State appeals court decision giving city right to temporarily evict homeless people from shelter system who violate regulations; says homeless advocates fear crucial decisions will fall to untrained workers who may not be able to distinguish between mental illness, which would exempt person from regulation, and social dysfunction (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The government is facing considerable skepticism from managed care companies and drug makers as chances grow that Congress will pass legislation to provide prescription drug coverage to the elderly. Officials of the private health plans that the Bush administration says are crucial to the benefit's success are particularly wary, given their own troubled history with the Medicare program. Trying to provide health care coverage of the elderly for less money, Congress encouraged health plans in the mid-1980's to offer them Medicare health maintenance organizations. But in recent years, government payments for the companies' services have lagged well behind their surging costs, and many plans have dropped out of the program or reduced the services they provide.
